utterances: The biggest thing is, you know, just reaching out to survivors and dispelling myths.
You know, as much as I hate rumors and gossip in the United States, they don't kill me.
But in Ghana, you know, where people think if you put change in your bra, that can get - you can get breast cancer that way.
There's so many different, crazy myths of how you can acquire the disease, and treatments, that if you go to the hospital, you're going to die there.
They're going to cut off your boobs and you're going to die anyway.
So just getting the word out, showing people that there are survivors, this doesn't have to mean a death sentence, and pointing people in direction of a treatment.

We actually dedicated a hospital that, among other things, is geared towards improving breast health in terms of early diagnosis, which leads to early treatment, which leads to a greater chance of survival.
And at this hospital in Kumasi, that's - breast cancer treatment is one of the focal points there in terms of treatment.
And people were itching to tell their stories.
Certainly the survivors - I met a girl who is 17, who'd already survived three different battles with breast cancer at 17, which kind of got my passion flowing to reach out to even younger people.
But it's never too early to take, you know, care of your breasts and to be aware of your body, and to kind of keep everything aligned, mind, body and spirit.
But yeah, just talking to the survivors and hearing their stories.
And some are heartwarming and inspirational, and some were, you know, depressing.
There were a number of women whose husbands left them.
A number of women whose children couldn't be married, because they felt like a curse had been placed upon their family, and their families wouldn't accept them.
You know, my goal is sort of to lessen those unfortunate stories, and have so many more stories of hope and inspiration and survival.
When celebrities get involved with a cause, it does make a material difference.
And there's this interesting intersection of arts, culture, celebrity, activism, social change.
Do you think that it helped to be able to have the power that you have as an actress and as someone who's been committed to social change and to be able to go over there?
No, I mean, definitely.
You know, unfortunately, when all the professors and the researchers and the scientists came, unfortunately the press didn't show up.
They're the ones with all the great information that can save your life.
I can just sort of regurgitate it in, you know, using a little bit more plain language.
But you know, fortunately or unfortunately, celebs bring media.
And media is able to, you know, reach such a greater amount of people.
Unfortunately, that's sort of the way it's become and how it's set up these days.
And I love the position that I'm in.
I have so much to say and hopefully, you know, I'd like to use my voice to help people as opposed to, you know, furthering just my own personal causes.
But, you know, to try to create change in a positive way, certainly in the black community, on a global scale.
This conversation reminds me of the role that you played in the movie ""Cadillac Records."" And you play a woman who - I believe her name's Geneva Wade?
Yes.
Who is Muddy Waters' life partner, you know, first girlfriend, wife.
And without revealing too much, she has a certain relationship to her health as a woman that seems to shape their relationship.

I thought that moment where you discussed that in the movie was really interesting, because it does relate to this overall idea of, you know, women's health and how it shapes our greater relationships to the world.
What did you like about that character?
What did you like about the role, or how was it playing that role?
You know, I loved the character.
One of my biggest challenges was to not judge the character.
My acting coach is like, it's your job to find her truth and give her dignity and integrity.
It's not your job to judge her in her choices.
This is a real woman who made her own choices, and she had a different line in the sand than you may have, or a lot of other women may claim to have.
But the reality is, you know, every woman I've - I know and love has been Geneva.
She's been the woman that stayed, whether we talk about it or not.
We tend to tell the stories where, you know, you leave in a blaze of glory and there's some sort of Lorena Bobbitt moments, you know.
Those are the stories we'd like to share with our girlfriends and our family members.
But you know, every woman I know has stayed and for their own reasons.

And with Geneva's situation, she felt like because she couldn't have any more kids, it was kind of, you know, and he was still good to her, that - his version of good to her, I'm using my finger quotes - was more than she deserved as a human being.
And you know, all of my friends who came to the premiers and have seen the movies, they were like, you know, thank you for not showing her as weak.
Well the movie really deals with this transition from the blues into rock and roll.
How did that resonate with you?
The whole idea of this music and the social change, the transformation and all of this, and the kind of - the raw power and greed, sensuality, all the epic stuff.

We had the chance to speak to Viola Davis recently about her role in the movie ""Doubt."" And one of the things she said was that, I want to be able to own all of the landscape in acting, all of the portrayals of humanity in the context of being a black actress, you know, who's gone back and forth between theater and film.
How do you feel black actresses are doing with that territory and being able to claim the range, and being able to get roles that have range?
You know, I would love to sit here and lie to you and say, well you know, Barack's in the office and things are changing, Ally won an Oscar.
Yeah, it doesn't work like that.
Unfortunately, our terrain is shrinking.
That's just because there's just not as many films being green lit, there's as not as many films being made.
Please submit all ethnicities, you know, used to be code word for, send us your black actresses, your weak, you know, your huddled masses yearning to break free.
But now, that's pretty much everybody, and all clamoring for a few jobs.
And out of those few jobs, one might be a great nugget, you know, a great acting piece that's going to challenge you.
So it's a little bleak.
And, you know, I've tried to look at it as, if you're not part of the solution, you're part of the problem.

So I'm trying to be part of the solution and, you know, I'm creating projects, certainly for myself, and ideally for, you know, my fellow, you know, actresses of all hues, but certainly for African-American actresses.
It's great to hear that.
And it's great to see you again, and fingers and toes.
Yeah.
Thank you.
I do appreciate it.

Greg and Mary Catherine O'Brien have lived in their house on Cape Cod for more than 30 years.

It's that time of the year again when, in the name of peace on Earth and goodwill toward men, we all end up doing something we hate.

And like lemmings to the sea, we schlep the kids to the nearest performance of the ""Nutcracker Ballet."" I know it's a holiday classic, one of those cultural must-dos, like piano recitals and modern art.
But, honestly, is there anyone over the age of eight who actually enjoys sitting through that ballet?
Don't get me wrong, I think everybody should see the ""Nutcracker"" at least once.
But, really, even when it's staged by the best, it's not what you would consider white-hot entertainment.
Sure, the costumes are pretty, and the music is, too.
But the story--it's as old and tired as ""Mr.
Magoo's Christmas Carol."" Girl gets nutcracker.
Girl breaks nutcracker.
Girl gets dragged to Sugarland, where she's forced to sit through a lineup of talent that would make Simon Cowell cry.
Face it, ""Harry Potter"" it's not.
I'm not saying we should get rid of the ballet altogether.
As sappy as it is, it's still a great way to introduce kids to overall music and dance.
And there's something to be said for taking two hours out of the year to simply sit still and appreciate art.
But if the ""Nutcracker"" ever hopes to truly compete with Xbox games and iPods, it needs an extreme makeover.
I don't mean staging the show on ice or transforming it into a Barbie video, both of which have already been done.
I'm talking about something radical, something that will make the ballet more ""Survivor"" than Sugar Plum Fairy.
Maybe instead of the Snowflake Dance, there should be skateboarders doing nosegrinds and kickflips.
Maybe Clara should be chauffeured to the Land of Sweets in a souped-up NASCAR.
Or the audience could get into the act.
They could dream up some Donald Trump-like challenges for the cast to do.
They could watch the coffee and chocolate dances and then take a vote to see which tutu should be tossed from the footlights.
OK, maybe that's going too far.
But, trust me, when you find yourself wedged in a dark theater seat, dozing through yet another round of ""Waltz of Flowers,"" my plan for skateboarders won't sound all that bad.
